awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT:  Novel Silicon Photovoltaics for Efficient and Low-cost Conversion of Heat to Electricity
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to improve storage of energy created by solar cells.  photovoltaics. The proposed technology is designed for use in utility-scale stationary electricity storage systems, or thermal batteries, with a novel systems architecture.  This project will demonstrate a low-cost approach to energy storage using earth-abundant storage materials and able to be deployed virtually anywhere in the world. 

The proposed project advances a cost-effective form of photovoltaic cell with a novel architecture.  This system utilizes incident thermal radiation with near-perfect efficiency. The objective of the project is to design and demonstrate a scalable airbridge silicon thermophotovoltaic (TPV) technology that achieves sufficiently high efficiencies to enable the deployment of thermal batteries. The project will also explore the integration of the TPV cells with high-temperature thermal storage media to provide design guidelines for future system-level demonstration projects. Overall, the proposed project will provide a more complete understanding of how the airbridge architecture can enable an energy system that provides long-duration energy storage at a significantly lower cost than existing approaches.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on developing a scalable solid-state technology designed to efficiently convert thermal radiation into electricity. The intention is to apply this technology in utility-scale stationary electricity storage systems known as thermal batteries. These systems combine thermal photovoltaic (TPV) cells with cost-effective thermal energy storage (TES), presenting a promising solution for achieving complete decarbonization of the electricity grid. Despite the promise, the current scalability of TPV devices falls short of the necessary levels. To bridge this gap, the project merged the advantages of silicon photovoltaics, the most cost-effective PV cells available, with a novel cell architecture recently discovered by the researchers, which features near-perfect efficiency in utilizing incident radiation. The core objective was to design and demonstrate a scalable airbridge Si TPV technology that achieved the requisite high efficiencies for thermal battery deployment. Additionally, the project delved into integrating Si TPV arrays with high-temperature thermal sources, thereby providing valuable design insights for forthcoming system-level demonstration projects.

Over the research period, several noteworthy achievements were realized. The project successfully demonstrated a scalable airbridge silicon TPV technology, showcasing improvements in efficiency suitable for integration into thermal batteries. The incorporation of the air-bridge architecture resulted in a discernible increase in TPV efficiency, with an absolute enhancement of approximately 5% across all temperature evaluations (equivalent to a relative increase of 30%). This improvement was attributed to very low parasitic absorption. Furthermore, the research extended to the fabrication of Si airbridge modules, facilitated by the establishment of a systematic approach involving the cold-weld bonding technique for array creation. Testing of these prototype arrays under conditions of high-temperature thermal illumination validated key performance characteristics. 

In parallel, members of the project team completed the NSF I-Corps program. The collaborative efforts of both PhD students acting as co-Entrepreneurial Leads, alongside Technical Lead Andrej Lenert, and Industry Mentor Greg Olsen from GHO Ventures, resulted in a comprehensive customer discovery effort. Customer interviews aimed to impartially comprehend the potential market for thermophotovoltaic devices. The outcomes highlighted significant demand among thermal battery engineers for accessible high-performance TPV devices. Additionally, the interviews identified promising prospects within the domain of industrial waste energy scavenging, thus expanding the technology's potential applications. The I-Corps experience inspired the project team to engage three undergrads and a resaearch engineer to create a significant practical demonstration of a Si TPV panel that provides wall plug AC power to small appliances.

Collectively, the project fostered a deeper comprehension of how the airbridge architecture could unlock the potential of an energy system offering prolonged-duration energy storage at a substantially reduced cost compared to existing methods.
